E d W ard B onks

Thanksgiving has another sad
memory which also begins the
bestive season - my paternal
grandmother, Ella Haridson died
on that day eight years ago. Her

one child, one grandchild and two
brothers, likewise recall happier
days.


Time passes, you are here, you
are there, you may have all or
nothing, but time evades no one.

a monument raised in his or
her memory in every state of the
land and in every seat of gov
eminent in the world.


The Latins properly remarked,
"tempus fugit." The old English
said. lyme runneth swiftly"
Early Caveman doubtedlessly
grunted, ugh goes--ugh." The
rise of the sun on an unknown
and unsung person-resulted in
our daily race with the clock.


My life and yours is measured.
Philosophers may disagree but
a mans days have been thought
by some sages to have been
carefully measured when he first
breathes of life. This idea of
predestination leaves little for
us to plan or ponder.


Others feel that man is the ul-
innate judge of his fate and all
or nothing depends upon his &C
tions alone. This idea leaves too
much to ponder and plan.


There Is middle of the road
.course--we are products of SUI
preme being who through divine
guidance allows us to plan and
ponder a portion of our earthly
existence.


Theologians have questioned
and reconciled their expoundings
since the first oracle was quoted
from ancient Delphi by the Greek
freethinkers.


The world is too much with US
late and so on-mused one great
writer, who was not concerned
with any particular belief in
mans existence or his demise.
We are born and we must learn
to live within a certain span of
seconds, hours, minutes, days
and weeks.


Time can be fascinating. Time
can be frightening. Time can be
joyful. Time can be sadness.
Time can be full of hope or
filled with despair.


There is a mystery in time.
That time--the time--it' S time
are beginning phrases which can
evoke numerous plans, events
and occurrences.


One of the most exciting times
comes during the month between
Thanksgiving and Christmas Eve.
The whole city seems to awaken
and the faces of the people seem
to get an inner glow.


The houses are bright at night
lighted by season welcoming
glows from trees and wreaths.
The city streets are shining with
extra shimmers of lights and gay
decorations.


From window or the glimmer
of Christmas tree lights can be
seen at least two weeks before
the long awaited eve.


There is an air of anticipa-
tion among the children. Many
of them seem a bit angelic. They
seem to sense that this is the
time to be good.


The bustling shoppers in the
crowded store aisles remember
to say a "pardon me" or manage
a smile when bumped or pushed.
More doors are held open for
ladies'. More pedestrians are al
lowed to walk and not run on the
caution sign. More CHEEKY greet
ings ring through the air.


Guess what must
be nearl It's happiness to have
it on the way - but a bit sad,
too. There are two important
events in our family which hap
pened on Christmas Day. First,
the matriarch of our family,
Mrs. Minnie Waterman, my mater
nal grandmother will celebrate
